messageBody:
didoss@... wrote:

> I'd go for some basic checkbook program (like a really stripped down
> Quicken, or the likes) - as everybody understands that,...or some
> similar concept that is familiar in an everyday life, and therefore
> easy to explain.
>
> If you stick with something that is really scalable, then you (or
> they) can scale to any level,...for both functionality and GUI.
>
> For functionality - small scale is text file of data with basic
> command line options to input/retrieve data (deposit, withdrawal,
> balance),...medium scale is maybe still flat file data with more
> diverse command options (max/min/avg balance),...even add in
> functionality to put your data in buckets (descretionary/mandatory
> spending; type of spending - groceries, books, clothes, recreation,
> etc) to be able to drill down to different levels - "how much money
> did I spend each quarter at the bookstore buying new books on Java,
> JUnit, etc.?"
>
> For GUI - small scale is various command line options to
> input/retrieve data,...medium scale is mildly interesting GUI to ease
> input/retrieval,...work your way up to a better GUI with some bells
> and whistles,...even add in functionality to do bars, graphs, etc. -
> "how much money did I spend each quarter at the bookstore buying new
> books on Java, JUnit, etc.?"
>
> -------------- Original message --------------
> I'm developing a course on test driven development and JUnit. This
> course will be taught in a variety of formats and lengths ranging from
> 90-minute seminar to one or two day hands on tutorial to a traditional
> university setting. Obviously how much I can cover and how deep I can go
> will vary depending on format, length, and audience level.
>
> I'm wondering if anyone has any good ideas for examples to use in this
> course? Ideally I'd like something that's simple enough to do in a day,
> but still gives attendees a feeling that they've developed something
> real. I could possibly do something involving the Mandelbrot set or
> cellular automata. However, I'd prefer something a little less
> mathematical if possible.
>
> I'd like it to have a GUI component, but at the same time I'd like that
> to show up fairly late in the application, and for the application to
> still make sense if there's not time to cover testing GUIs.
>
> It should be possible to develop this program on a laptop not connected
> to the Internet. i.e. no databases access, network communications, web
> services, the U.S. tax code, and so forth.
>
> Students will have a wide variety of backgrounds so I want to avoid any
> special knowledge of subjects like XML processing, financial
> derivatives, quantum physics, and so forth. I should be able to cover
> the background necessary to start writing the program in 10 minutes or
> less.
>
> Any ideas?
>
> --
